Package fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.examples.hioa_with_vh

DEVS simulation example: HIOA models with value histories.

See: Description

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    HIOA_Consumer
    The class HIOA_Consumer defines an HIOA model that imports a variable otherCurrent and evaluates it each time it is triggered and sets its own internal variable myCurrent to the obtained new value.
    HIOA_CoupledModel
    The class HIOA_CoupledModel defines a coupled model for the HIOA with value history example.
    HIOA_Generator
    The class HIOA_Counter implements a simple real time HIOA atomic model that receives an external event TicEvent and counts them in an exported variable generated.
    HIOA_Multiplier
    The class HIOA_Multiplier implements a simple HIOA model which imports a double type model variable from which it computes an exported model variable mine by applying some multiplication factor.
    SimulationMain
    The class SimulationMain runs the simulation of models using value histories to evaluate continuous variables.
    TicEvent
    The class TicEvent implements a tic event emitted by a a model that tics at some pace.
    TicModel
    The class TicModel implements an atomic model that emits tic events at a regular frequency given by a run parameter.

Package fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.examples.hioa_with_vh Description

DEVS simulation example: HIOA models with value histories.

Licence

Copyright Jacques Malenfant, Sorbonne Universite.

Jacques.Malenfant@lip6.fr

This software is a computer program whose purpose is to provide a new implementation of the DEVS simulation de facto standard for Java.

This software is governed by the CeCILL-C license under French law and abiding by the rules of distribution of free software. You can use, modify and/ or redistribute the software under the terms of the CeCILL-C license as circulated by CEA, CNRS and INRIA at the following URL http://www.cecill.info.

As a counterpart to the access to the source code and rights to copy, modify and redistribute granted by the license, users are provided only with a limited warranty and the software's author, the holder of the economic rights, and the successive licensors have only limited liability.

In this respect, the user's attention is drawn to the risks associated with loading, using, modifying and/or developing or reproducing the software by the user in light of its specific status of free software, that may mean that it is complicated to manipulate, and that also therefore means that it is reserved for developers and experienced professionals having in-depth computer knowledge. Users are therefore encouraged to load and test the software's suitability as regards their requirements in conditions enabling the security of their systems and/or data to be ensured and, more generally, to use and operate it in the same conditions as regards security.

The fact that you are presently reading this means that you have had knowledge of the CeCILL-C license and that you accept its terms.

This package provides a first DEVS simulation example with HIOA models using value histories and inter/extrapolation for the evaluation of model variables at time instants that do not correspond with evaluation time instants.

The organisation of the models are as follows:

  • a model instance of TicModel emits events of type TicEvent at a chosen rate (see the run parameters) towards another model instance of HIOA_Generator;
  • the model instance of HIOA_Generator reacts to the reception of a TicEvent (external transition) by triggering an immediate internal transition which increments an exported variable by 1;
  • the model variable generated of the HIOA_Generator is imported as a model variable other by a model instance of HIOA_Multiplier which is triggered at another chosen rate (see again the run parameters) to compute another model variable mine which value is obtained by multiplying the value of the variable other by a factor that is also chosen;
  • finally, a third model instance of HIOA_Consumer imports the variable mine of HIOA_Multiplier as its own variable otherCurrent and is also triggered at a chosen rate (see again the run parameters) to set the value of its internal model variable myCurrent.

This example shows how to use the fix point initialisation protocol for HIOA models as dependencies exist between models variables. It also shows how to use and the potential impact of value histories and inter/extrapolation. To see the difference, a command line argument controls whether the run uses inter/extrapolation or not. In fact, the class SimulationMain has two command line arguments: the first tells whether the run is in real time or not, the second whether it uses inter/extrapolation or not. The javadoc of SimulationMain gives the results that must be obtained in the two cases.
